derniè res de l'étage senonieu"

6. The first approach towards a more accurate knowledge of the
real nature of the Orbitolite, <s>by</s> through an examination of its internal
structure, was made (I believe) by myself, in my Memoir "On
the Microscopic Structure of <u>Nummulina, Orbitolites</u>, and
<u>Orbitoides</u>, read before the Geological Society of London on
November 1849, and published in its Quarterly Journal for 
February 1850. The place assigned to this genus in the system of
M D'Orbigny not having been at that time made public; and
all other Zoologists & Palaeontologists having ranked it in close
approximation to <u>Lunnulites</u> and other Polyparies of the 
Bryozoic (Polyzoic) kind, I entered upon the examination
without the least suspicion that this organism was to be regarded
in any other light; and that I was not undeceived in the course
of it, may be attributed to the small number of specimens then
placed at my disposal for the <s>purpose</s> enquiry by my late friend Prof.
E Forbes, and to the circumstance that these specimens were
of the type that presents most resemblance to that of a Bryozoic
polypary, and were all deficient in the central nucleus which
